questions.text: A 23-year-old woman with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is brought to the emergency department with pain and swelling of the right knee after she twisted it while dancing. She had two similar episodes last year that were treated conservatively. She was treated for a fracture of her humerus 2 years ago. She has gastroesophageal reflux disease. Her sister has allergic rhinitis. Her only medication is omeprazole. She appears tense and uncomfortable. Her temperature is 37.1°C (99.3°F), pulse is 97/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows mild scoliosis. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows a mid-systolic click. The right knee shows a large, tender effusion and the patella is displaced laterally. Lachman test, posterior drawer test, and Apley test are negative. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference range. Toxicology screening is negative. X-ray of the knee joint shows an osteochondral fragment within the knee joint. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In a patient with a patellar dislocation and a concurrent osteochondral fracture, knee arthroscopy is the initial procedure indicated to either repair the osteochondral defect or remove the intraarticular fragment if a repair cannot be performed. Following removal of the fragment, reduction is performed intraoperatively, and the knee is flexed and extended through its entire range of motion.

Individuals with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome often present with joint hypermobility, which puts them at increased risk for joint dislocations (especially of the knee and shoulder).

B) INCORRECT:

Above-knee casts are rarely used to immobilize the knee after the initial treatment of patellar dislocations nowadays because prolonged immobilization is associated with a higher risk of restricted joint movement, while early physiotherapy and functional bracing are associated with better outcomes. If fracture of the distal femur or tibia occurs along with patellar dislocation, an above-knee cast may be used for immobilization after initial treatment. However, such injuries occur only following high-energy trauma, and neither x-ray nor the patient's clinical presentation suggest femoral or tibial fractures.

C) INCORRECT:

A knee brace alone is unlikely to help this patient in the acute phase immediately following her injury. Following initial treatment, a knee brace that can be locked in extension (knee immobilizer) is used for 10–14 days. After 2 weeks, a functional brace can be used until the patient can walk without a limp.

D) INCORRECT:

This is a good answer option to consider because closed reduction of the patella is the treatment of choice in cases of uncomplicated patellar dislocation. This question aims at testing the management of patella dislocation complicated by an osteochondral fracture, which is seen in approximately 30–40% of patients with acute patellar dislocation. The osteochondral fracture should be repaired or removed before reducing the patellar dislocation to prevent osteochondral damage, which can occur during reduction as a result of shearing forces.

E) INCORRECT:

Recurrent patellar dislocation predisposes the patient to develop patellofemoral osteoarthritis of the knee, which may be treated with knee replacement surgery in severe cases. However, total knee replacement is not indicated to treat acute patellar dislocation.

F) INCORRECT:

Early physiotherapy minimizes muscle atrophy and maintains range of motion of the knee, which is why it plays an important role following the initial treatment of patellar dislocation. Strengthening exercises are continued for 3–4 months and help prevent recurrence of patellar dislocation by strengthening both the static stabilizers (ligaments) and the dynamic stabilizers (quadriceps muscles) of the knee joint and patella. However, physiotherapy does not play a role in the initial management of acute patellar dislocation.
questions.hint: A laterally displaced patella, right knee effusion and pain, a past history of similar episodes, and a history of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome make the diagnosis of acute patellar dislocation highly likely. The osteochondral fragment within the knee joint indicates an avulsion fracture of the lateral femoral condyle or patella.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old female cheerleader presents to the emergency department saying that she dislocated her knee. While at cheerleading practice, she landed awkwardly on her right leg and twisted her knee. She felt an immediate pop and noted an obvious knee deformity, which resolved on its own when she straightened her leg. She had immediate knee swelling and has been unable to ambulate. She has had no prior injuries to her knees.
Her knee is held in partial flexion. A large effusion is evident over the right knee joint. There is no obvious deformity. She has tenderness to palpation over her medial patella, and she stops the examiner from pushing the patella laterally because she feels apprehensive about this. She has a negative Lachman test, negative anterior and posterior drawer tests, and a negative McMurray test. Her knee is stable with varus and valgus stress. Neurologic and vascular examinations are normal.
A radiograph of the knee reveals no features of a fracture or other abnormality.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

choices.text: Rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament
Tear of the medial collateral ligament

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A true knee dislocation is much more likely to occur after a higher-force impact and is unlikely to be correctable by the patient. A knee, rather than a patellar, dislocation should be suspected when three or more knee ligaments have been disrupted, even if the patient is neurovascularly intact. This requires further evaluation by an orthopedic surgeon.

B) INCORRECT:

A medial meniscus tear also manifests with pain over the medial joint line and may have an associated effusion, especially if the injury is acute. The patient usually complains of locking or popping, and a McMurray test will often be positive. A McMurray test is performed by placing one hand over the joint line and the other hand on the patient’s foot. The leg is then bent to 90 degrees and externally rotated while providing a valgus stress with extension. This test is positive if either a pain or a pop is elicited.

C) CORRECT:

Patients who present acutely after a lateral patellar dislocation frequently report that they have dislocated their knee but have been able to correct it themselves. The only clue to the diagnosis may be a large knee effusion (which prevents full knee extension) and a positive apprehension test. An apprehension test involves applying pressure on the medial side of the patella while the knee is flexed. The test is positive if the patient has pain or tightens his or her muscles in anticipation of pain or a because of a feeling of instability.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in an athlete who has twisted her knee and has a stable ligament examination, a large effusion, a positive apprehension test, and a normal knee radiograph is patellar dislocation.

D) INCORRECT:

Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injuries occur at a higher rate among women engaged in pivoting sports than among men engaged in the same sports. ACL tears may occur after a twisting injury and may manifest with a large effusion, but the anterior drawer and Lachman tests would be positive in a patient with an ACL tear. A Lachman test is performed by stabilizing the femur and tibia and then trying to anteriorly translate the tibia on the femur; the test is positive if no firm endpoint is felt. An anterior drawer test is performed by flexing the patient’s knee to 75 degrees and then applying an anterior force on the tibia; the test is positive if there is anterior translation of the tibia from the femur. A Lachman test is more sensitive than an anterior drawer test for ACL rupture; the contralateral knee should always be inspected to determine any possible laxity that is present without injury.

E) INCORRECT:

A medial collateral ligament tear manifests with pain over the medial joint line and tenderness over the medial collateral ligament. If a grade II or III sprain is present, there is laxity with valgus stress. Isolated medial collateral ligament tears rarely manifest with a large effusion unless there is another concomitant injury.

questions.text: A 16-year-old basketball player presents to the emergency department with knee pain after landing awkwardly during a game. He reports immediate severe pain and feeling his knee give way. On examination, the patella appears laterally displaced with some joint effusion. Knee x-ray is shown. After successful reduction and pain management, what is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discharge with crutches and NSAIDs only
Restrict to partial weight-bearing with walker assistance
Obtain MRI to evaluate for ligament injury

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immobilization is essential after patellar dislocation to allow injured soft tissue to heal and prevent recurrence. Discharge without immobilization increases the risk of repeat dislocation.

B) INCORRECT:

Arthroscopy is indicated if conservative management is unsuccessful or patients have associated osteochondral fractures or significant soft tissue injuries. It is not appropriate for uncomplicated first-time dislocations that can be managed conservatively.

C) INCORRECT:

Following patellar dislocation, weight-bearing as tolerated rather than partial weight-bearing is recommended. Partial weight-bearing is unnecessarily restrictive, does not facilitate healing, and may cause muscle atrophy and deconditioning. In addition, immobilization of the knee is required after patellar dislocation.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Following successful reduction of a first-time patellar dislocation without fractures, the knee should be immobilized for up to 6 weeks with weight-bearing as tolerated.

E) INCORRECT:

MRI may be indicated for recurrent dislocations, preoperative planning, fractures, or hemarthrosis. However, MRI not routinely required after successful reduction of a first-time dislocation without fractures.
